TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , who had several convictions and had served a number of prison terms , was charged with the theft of construction material from a warehouse . It was alleged that he had been one of the members of a group that had committed thefts .

CARDINAL . The applicant did not appear when summoned for questioning and on CARDINAL DATE he was arrested and remanded in custody , by order of an investigator or a prosecutor . He remained in detention throughout the investigation proceedings and the trial .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG acquitted the applicant . He was released on DATE .

CARDINAL . Upon the prosecutor 's appeal , the acquittal was upheld by ORG on DATE . ORG found , inter alia , that at the outset there had been clearly insufficient proof of the applicant 's involvement in the thefts . In particular , a police officer had testified that the only reason for suspecting the applicant had been the presence of his name on an internal police list of nicknames as the person behind the nickname “ PERSON ” .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant brought an action against ORG , seeking damages in respect of his pre - trial detention . He relied on LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant sought non - pecuniary damages for the suffering caused by his pre - trial detention , which had lasted DATE , DATE and DATE . In his initial claim he sought CARDINAL “ old ” NORP levs ( “ ORG ” ) . In the course of the proceedings he increased the claim to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( the equivalent of approximately LAW ) , including interest , which in his view was to be calculated as from DATE , the date of his arrest .

CARDINAL . The Sofia City Court delivered its judgment on DATE . It held that the ORG was liable to pay all damage suffered by the applicant as a result of his “ unlawful pre - trial detention ” and the “ unlawful bringing of charges ” against him .
CARDINAL . The court stated , inter alia :

“ [ ORG ] has not exercised the necessary supervision over the GPE prosecutors and the investigation authorities which , during a period of [ DATE ] , mounted an unjustified criminal prosecution against [ the applicant ] on charges of theft ... They remanded him in custody , imposing the harshest measure of judicial control , which resulted in [ the applicant ] spending DATE and DATE [ sic ] DATE in detention ... As to the amount , the court considered that the length of the detention should be taken into consideration and rejected as unproven the applicant 's contention that his health had deteriorated as a consequence of his detention . Deciding on an equitable basis , the court awarded to the applicant BGL CARDINAL in non - pecuniary damages ( the equivalent of approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) plus interest from the date on which the applicant had been acquitted with final effect , DATE . CARDINAL . The court further applied section QUANTITY of ORG ( see paragraphs DATE below ) and ordered the applicant to pay BGL CARDINAL ( the equivalent of approximately EUR CARDINAL ) in court fees . That amount represented PERCENT of the dismissed part of the applicant 's claims .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG . He averred , inter alia , that the sum awarded in damages was too low and that it was unlawful to order him to pay court fees in an amount almost equal to the compensation award .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the appeal . As regards the court fees , it stated that section QUANTITY of ORG was unambiguous and required the payment of court fees proportionately to the dismissed part of the claim . In the applicant 's case , he had indicated an excessive amount in his claim and had thus himself brought about the situation complained of .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted a cassation appeal to ORG which was dismissed by judgment of DATE . As regards the costs , ORG reiterated the position taken by ORG . By setting his claims at an excessive level , the applicant himself had caused his liability for a substantial amount in court fees .

CARDINAL . In civil proceedings in GPE , the general rule is that court fees are payable by the plaintiff in advance , upon the submission of the claim ( LAW and sections DATE of LAW ) . A court fee at the flat rate of PERCENT is payable in respect of pecuniary claims ( Fees Schedule CARDINAL to LAW ) . Where the plaintiff succeeds fully or partly , the defendant is ordered to pay him his costs , including court fees , proportionately to the successful part of the claim .

CARDINAL . By section QUANTITY of ORG , in proceedings under LAW , no court fees or costs are payable by the plaintiff upon the submission of the claim . However , in circumstances where the claim is eventually wholly or partly dismissed , the court is to order the plaintiff to pay “ the court fees and costs due ” . The courts have interpreted the above provision as meaning that the plaintiff should pay court fees calculated as a pro rata percentage of the dismissed part of his claims . LAW provides for waiver of the fees in cases of indigence but concerns fees due upon the submission of the claim ( argument from ORG judgment no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL in case no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

Where the plaintiff indicated too high an amount in the claim form , the court fees may exceed the sum awarded in damages , the overall financial award being in favour of the ORG despite the finding that the plaintiff suffered damage which called for compensation under LAW ( see , for example , the following judgments of ORG : judgment no . CARDINAL of DATE , ORG ) .

The following DATE which draw on a summary report prepared by the research division of the ORG 's registry – describe relevant aspects of the system of court fees and costs in several member GPE representing different legal traditions , with emphasis on court fees in proceedings for damages against the ORG in cases where the respective domestic law provides for compensation for pre - trial detention .

CARDINAL . The general rule with regard to compensation claims lodged with an administrative court ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) is that a state fee of PERCENT of the amount claimed - but not CARDINAL kroons ( EUR CARDINAL ) and no more than in civil court proceedings concerning an equivalent amount – is charged when the claim is brought . In case non - pecuniary damages are claimed but the amount of the compensation is left to the discretion of the court , a simple fee of CARDINAL kroons ( EUR CARDINAL ) is due ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

LAW ( Riigi poolt isikule alusetult vabaduse võtmisega tekitatud kahju hüvitamise seadus ) , which concerns , inter alia , criminal proceedings that ended in acquittal or were discontinued , provides that the individual concerned can lodge a compensation request with ORG . No fees are involved . The amount of compensation is fixed by the LAW : it is DATE of the national DATE minimum salary ( enacted by the Government ) per day of detention . There is a presumption that this compensation covers non - pecuniary damage and loss of profit .

CARDINAL . Compensation for pecuniary damage is regulated by LAW . In accordance with section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( which came into force on DATE ) , no fee is payable on a claim lodged with an administrative court for pecuniary damage caused by deprivation of liberty .

CARDINAL . A claim for damages against the ORG can be brought under LAW . The court fee is approximately LAW , depending on the procedural actions undertaken by the court , regardless of the amount claimed .

CARDINAL/CARDINAL as amended ) or a civil action for damages under the aforementioned LAW . In either case no court fees are due in cases of detainees or acquitted persons .

CARDINAL . Since DATE the ORG has been responsible for paying court costs in respect of criminal proceedings . LAW provides for a right to be compensated for all pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage sustained as a result of pre - trial detention in cases of acquittal or discontinuation of the proceedings . The claim is filed with the President of ORG in whose area the criminal case was decided . All fees and costs in these proceedings are borne by the ORG .

CARDINAL . Actions for damages for unlawful detention are adjudicated by the civil courts . Proceedings for damages against the ORG may also be instituted before the administrative tribunals , where the wrongful conduct was imputable to the public administration .

CARDINAL . Court fees are in fixed amounts , irrespective of the sum claimed . The fees are different for first instance and appellate courts and modest in quantum : none of them exceeds LAW , according to the Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE .

CARDINAL . Actions for damages for unlawful detention are exempt from court fees ( Article CARDINAL ) of LAW ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . In proceedings involving compensation claims against the ORG , the maximum fee is the equivalent of approximately ORG CARDINAL ( Article CARDINAL(m ) of the Act ) . As to costs and expenses , at the conclusion of the proceedings , the losing party has to reimburse the other party 's costs and expenses .

CARDINAL . Claims for damages for unlawful detention are examined by ordinary courts in civil proceedings . Plaintiffs are exempt from court fees ( Article CARDINAL.CARDINAL , Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of LAW ) and the court can not order the plaintiff to pay such fees at the end of the proceedings , even if the claim was partially or fully dismissed .

CARDINAL . The successful party is entitled to the reimbursement of its costs . If an action succeeds only partly , the costs are divided proportionately between the parties ( Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . The defendant is required to pay into the federal budget a fee , from which the plaintiff is exempt , in proportion to the allowed part of the claim ( Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . There are CARDINAL possibilities for seeking damages for unlawful detention in GPE . The first is an administrative quasi - judicial procedure before the Chancellor of ORG , who can award compensation in fixed amounts . There is no fee for the claimant . The second possibility is a civil action for damages before the civil courts , for which a modest fixed court fee is payable regardless of the amount of the claim . Also , the claimant who loses the case must pay the other party 's costs

An action for damages against the state for unlawful detention is called a “ claim for false imprisonment ” which is treated as an action in trespass to the person ( i.e. a personal injury claim ) and is brought in the civil courts . Taking into account the money value of the claim and the complexity of the case , the court will allocate the case to CARDINAL of CARDINAL tracks : the “ small claims ” track , the “ fast - track ” or the “ multi - track . ” An action for false imprisonment is likely to be allocated to the multi - track .

CARDINAL . There are several types of court fees that the claimant has to pay in proceedings for false imprisonment . The first one is the “ issue fee ” , charged for filing the claim . It depends on the amount of money claimed in accordance with a decreasing table . For example , the issue fee for claims of MONEY ( ORG ) is GBP CARDINAL , for claims MONEY it is GBP CARDINAL and for claims MONEY it is GBP CARDINAL . The higher issue fee , charged for claims of GBP CARDINAL and higher , is GBP CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . When a defence is filed , the court allocates the case to a track and orders the claimant pay an “ allocation fee ” in the amount of £ MONEY ( except for claims not exceeding GBP CARDINAL for which no allocation fee is due ) . Finally , for matters that go to trial , a “ trial fee ” is payable as follows : in multi - track cases – GBP CARDINAL and in fast - track cases – GBP CARDINAL , no fee being due for small claims track cases .

CARDINAL . In respect of all fees , the court may decide that the claimant does not have to pay a court fee ( exemption ) , or that he / she may pay a smaller fee ( remission ) . That is usually done in cases involving indigent claimants .

CARDINAL . When deciding on the award to be granted to the claimant , the courts enjoy a wide power to limit the amount that a party may recover with regard to the trial costs . According to ORG , the court is “ to have regard to all the circumstances ” in determining what costs are payable ( r.CARDINAL.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Those circumstances specifically include those set out in r.CARDINAL.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , namely : ( a ) the procedural conduct of all the parties , including in particular , the efforts made , if any , before and during the proceedings in order to try to resolve the dispute ; ( b ) the amount involved ; ( c ) the importance of the matter to all the parties ; ( d ) the particular complexity of the matter or the difficulty or novelty of the questions raised ; ( e ) the skill , effort , specialised knowledge and responsibility involved and ( f ) the time spent on the case;.
